results.title: Bananas in pyjamas: rock-a-bye bananas
results.brief_description: 10 adventures featuring your favourite “Bananas in pajamas” characters. “Rock-a-bye bananas” (dir. David Evans, wri. Richard Tulloch): The bananas buy a hammock and struggle to construct it. “Magic Tolstoy” (dir. David Evans, wri. Simon Hopkinson): B1 and B2 are bamboozled by what appears to be two Tolstoys. “Tortoise wedding” (dir. David Evans, wri. Simon Hopkinson): Tolstoy and Thomasina are marrying and the B1 and B2 are best bananas. “Banana breakfast” (dir. Ian Munro, wri. Debra Oswald): After the teddys leave the bananas a hamper of food, the bananas decide to repay the favour by preparing a special breakfast. “Sneezing time” (dir. Ian Munro, wri. Debra Oswald): Amy buys a new fluffy red jumper and all of a sudden people are allergic to her. “Stepping on cracks” (dir. David Evans, wri. Debra Oswald): The bananas declare today “no stepping on cracks day” which leads to a competition. “Stuck inside” (dir. Ian Munro, wri. Debra Oswald): The teddys are stuck inside their house. “Bedtime bunyip” (dir. Ian Munro, wri. Chris Hawkshaw): B1 and B2 are reading a story about a bunyip and become spooked when they hear strange noises. “Speedy bananas” (dir. Ian Munro, wri. Debra Oswald): The Rat Olympics are on and Rat is winning every race. Amy comes up with a contest to beat him. “Lulu’s yo-yo” (dir. David Evans, wri. Simon Hopkinson): Lulu is upset when the store runs out of yo-yos so the bananas decide to make her one. This DVD also features 30 minutes of nursery rhymes to sing along with.

results.title: Bamiri: the story of a village that helped itself
results.brief_description: The story of a village that helped itself. When the villagers of Bamiri in Ashanti decided to build themselves a Community Centre they scarcely realised how this would stimulate the progress of the village. Now the people of Bamiri are not only improving their village materially, but they are educating themselves in many other ways. No other credits available.

results.title: Baltique Sea Plastique
results.brief_description: The Baltic Sea Plastique installation sets out to explore the complexity and controversial nature of the environmental threat caused by plastic waste.

constellations_other.name: Deep blue
constellations_other.description: Go deep on an exploration of real world oceans and those rendered by pixels and creatures made from plastics.

results.description: The word “plastic” derives from the Greek plastikos, meaning capable of being shaped or moulded (from plastos, “moulded”). It refers to the malleability or plasticity of the material.Plastic is a man-made material that has spread all over the world, and has led to so-called plastic pollution, which is almost impossible to clean up. The plasticity of plastics and their impact on the ecosystem are out of human control.The Baltic Sea Plastique installation sets out to explore the complexity and controversial nature of the environmental threat caused by plastic waste. The work combines the plasticity of visual arts with the creative and resilient capacity of marine life. The astonishing plastic beauty of marine creatures— all synthetic and made of plastic trash in the installation—evokes the formative process of nature. For better or for worse, plasticity is a testament to life’s metamorphic capability. Baltic Sea Plastique presents a plastic world of sensations in which synthetic and organic forms coexist, interact, and create puzzling natural artifacts. http://www.tuulanarhinen.net/artworks/baltplast.html

results.title: Balmain
results.creator_credit: Kit Guyatt and Sydney Filmmakers Co-operative
results.brief_description: Expresses the popular protest of residents in the inner Sydney suburb of Balmain against the industrial development of the foreshore as a major container shipping port. Discusses the historic buildings and traditional character of the area and the radical changes expected. Shows the problems of the city planning involved.

results.title: Balloons and spinifex
results.creator_credit: Ian Dunlop, John Gray, Shan Benson and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: The building of a weather station in the Australian desert, showing the work of those who run it and the use made of their reports by the Bureau of Meteorology. Based at the Giles Weather Station.

results.title: Balloon goes up
results.brief_description: During the reign of King Louis XVI, the Motgolfier brothers invented the hot air balloon. Pierre Olaf narrates an animated account of the balloon flight in which the first living creatures, a duck, a sheep, and a rooster, were sent aloft in Versailles, France. No other credits available.

results.title: Ballet with Edward Villella
results.creator_credit: William Francisco, Robert Saudek and Learning Corporation of America
results.brief_description: Edward Villella, lead dancer with the New York City Ballet, dissolves the notion that male dancers are ‘sissified’ in a montage of dances demonstrating the muscular control necessary in his art. Shows how the body is made into a smoothly working organism while expressing ideas and feelings. Includes excerpts from NYC Ballet productions.

results.title: Ballet robotique
results.brief_description: A humorous entertaining look at the use of robots in American industry. Many of the robots movements are set to classical music and they are shown replacing humans in tedious and hazardous tasks. Music played by the Royal Philharmonic Orchestra.

results.title: Ballet class with Madame Ninette de Valois
results.brief_description: A senior students’ class at the Royal Ballet School, is directed through a series of barre, centre and pointe exercises by Madame De Valois.

results.title: Ballet Black
results.brief_description: Formed in 1946, Ballet Negres was the first all black dance company in Europe. It reached its creative and popular peak between 1948 and 1950 but by 1952 it had dissolved. The company created a unique style, fusing Afro Carribean dance with classical ballet. It used mime as a third distinctive element to develop a narrative reflecting Black/White relations and Black folklore. The film explores the Ballet Negres story, using reviews, news coverage and showing a reunion of the original members. Young dancers are also seen rehearsing and performing the ballet “They Came”.
